OHIO VOLUME II INCLUDED IN VOLUME II ARE THE SIX TOWNSHIPS OF NIMISHILLEN. OSNABURG. SANDY. PIKE. BETHLEHEM. AND SUGAR CREEK_ 1 DATE MICIlOFiCHED I j MAY 1 8 1990 ir, PROJECT and i FiCHH * / G. S. CALL # ^/6 ?f/OS. 607^6 SY .£ PREPARED BY THE MEMBERS OF THE STARK COUNTY CHAPTER THE OHIO GENEALOGICAL SOCIETY JULY 1. 1982 GENEMOG'^GAL DEPARTMENT LATTER-DAY SAINTS ii FOREWORD Almost three generations have passed since 1900 which was the cutoff date for tombstone inscriptions in the last book which covered the entire county. Although typed, that book was never published and its use was restricted to a few libraries. It is an ambitious project to cover the entire 195 cemeteries in Stark County, Ohio. Volume I was the beginning. Volume II is the continua- tion of that effort. Ten of the seventeen townships have now been covered. IN MEMORIAM This, the second volume of Cemetery Inscriptions of Stark County, Ohio is dedicated to the memory of: CHESTER L. STERLING (1898-1979) Chester L. Sterling was the first vice president of the Stark County Chap- ter of The Ohio Genealogical Society and was responsible for the programs during the first year of its existence. An educator during most of his life he served as teacher, principal and superintendent in schools in the Pittsburgh area. He served overseas at the request of the State Department and then for the State of Ohio and the city of North Canton, where he had retired. He was an active genealogist and contributed much to the start of this organization. i ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS It is impossible to include the names of all of the people who have helped with the preparation of this book. Many of the inscriptions contained in this book were read by Evelyn Jessup, now deceased. Those who read each cemetery are listed at the end of each cemetery. Special recognition is given to the three typists: Hazel Murphy, Marty Thatcher and Dorothy Wig. Hazel Murphy also served as the Coordinator for the entire Cemetery Project, Acknowledgement is also given to the Stark County Historical Society for furnishing the photograph of McKinley's Monument on the cover and the 1910 map of Stark County shown on page vi. PREFACE iii Stark County, Ohio was formed in 1809 from Columbiana County. It subse- quently lost Brown, Harrison and Rose Townships to Carroll County in 1833 and Green and Franklin Townships to Summit County in 1840. It contains 17 townships today. Its cemeteries date from 1805 when the first settlers came. There are 195 cemeteries today. This volume covers the eastern townships of Nimishillen and Osnaburg which are adjacent to the townships covered in Volume I as well as the townships across the southern part of the county: Sandy, Pike, Bethlehem, and Sugar Creek. 81 cemeteries are included in these six townships. Much use has been made of the previous cemetery book entitled "Cemetery Records, Stark County, Ohio." It was researched by E. T. Heald, H. T. 0. Blue and H. D. Paxton. It was compiled, edited, indexed and with a foreword by Dorothy Sommer, Head, Reference Division, Canton Public Library Association, The project was sponsored by the Stark County Historical Society. It consisted of four volumes, one of which was the index, and was typed in 1955. It covered 158 cemeteries from the earliest time until 1900. Most of the inscriptions were copied in the 1940's. Much credit must be given to the researchers because many of the tombstones which they copied are unreadable or non-existent today. The map used by E. T. Heald to locate the cemeteries in the 1940' s was made available by Eva Sparrowgrove of The Stark County Historical Society. In this volume the cemetery numbers assigned by Heald have continued to be used. The description of the locations of the cemeteries in Stark County was submitted by Marilyn Oyster and Evelyn Jessup to The Ohio Genealogical Society for inclusion in their 1978 book entitled "Ohio Cemeteries", which lists the location of every cemetery in the State of Ohio. The same descriptions are used in this volume and will be used in all volumes to be published in the future. An attempt has been made to read the tombstones in rows so that an indivi- dual could locate a particular stone from the descriptions. This has not always been possible because of the haphazard manner in which some cemeteries are laid out. All stones have been included to the present day. Stones illegible or missing, but listed in Heald 's book, have been included and are so indicated. Additional volumes to be published in the future will cover the remaining seven townships. Much work remains to be done but it will be accomplished and the project completed. ^^ TABLE OF CONTENTS Page FOREWARD, IN MEMORIAM, ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS ii PREFACE iii MAP OF STARK COUNTY vi NIMISHILLEN TOWNSHIP 1.
